{{good article}} {{Infobox winter storm|name=January 1992 nor'easter |image location=Jan 92 storm sat.png |image name=Satellite image of the nor'easter |stormtype=[[Nor'easter]] |date formed=January 2, 1992 |date dissipated=January 4, 1992 |pressure={{convert|993|mb|inHg|abbr=on}}<ref name="chl"/> |gust={{convert|89|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} at [[Chincoteague, Virginia]] |total damages (USD)=$63 million (1992 [[United States dollar|USD]]) |total fatalities=1 total |areas affected=[[Mid-Atlantic States]], [[New England]]}} The '''January 1992 nor'easter''' was the second in a series of [[nor'easter]]s in a 14-month period that produced strong winds, high tides, and flooding along the [[East Coast of the United States]]. It was a small, short-lived storm that was poorly forecast, intensifying rapidly on January 4 before striking the [[Eastern Shore of Virginia]]. The strongest quadrant of the storm moved over Delaware, and winds in the state reached {{convert|58|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. The nor'easter weakened as it moved westward, and it dissipated over Virginia before the energy reformed and redeveloped offshore.
In North Carolina, the storm flooded the main highway connecting the [[Outer Banks]]. The nor'easter struck shortly during a new moon, producing high tides that resulted in significant beach erosion along the [[Delmarva Peninsula]]. The highest wind gust was {{convert|89|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}, reported in [[Chincoteague, Virginia]]. The cost of the lost beach near [[Ocean City, Maryland]] was estimated at over $10 million (1992 [[United States dollar|USD]]). In the city, the storm destroyed the tidal gauge, although the [[storm surge]] was estimated at {{convert|6.6|ft|m|abbr=on}}. The strongest quadrant of the storm moved over Delaware; in the state, strong easterly winds produced significant tidal flooding, and 500 houses were damaged. A high tide of {{convert|9.02|ft|m|abbr=on}} at [[Dewey Beach, Delaware|Dewey Beach]] was the second highest tide on record in the entire state. Flooding also affected [[South Jersey]] in many areas that experienced flooding from the [[1991 Perfect Storm]] in the previous October. Damage was estimated at $45 million (1992 USD). Strong winds reached as far north as [[New York (state)|New York]], where a fallen tree seriously injured a person driving a car. Freezing rain associated with the storm caused a traffic fatality in New York, as well as several accidents in Maine.
==Meteorological history== On January 2, a small [[low pressure area]] developed along the [[East Coast of the United States]]. Due to its small size, the storm was [[weather forecasting|poorly forecast]].<ref name="chl"/> A strong [[cold-core low|upper-level low]] moving through Georgia and South Carolina caused the low to move to the west, perpendicular to the Mid-Atlantic coast.<ref name="dgs">{{cite report|author=Kelvin W. Ramsey|author2=John H. Talley|date=June 1992|publisher=Delaware Geological Survey|title=Summary Report: The Storm of January 4, 1992|accessdate=2012-03-18|url=http://www.dgs.udel.edu/sites/dgs.udel.edu/files/publications/OFR36.pdf|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120429194114/http://www.dgs.udel.edu/sites/dgs.udel.edu/files/publications/OFR36.pdf|archivedate=April 29, 2012|df=}}</ref> As it did so, the combination of warm air from the south and strong upper-level winds caused the low to [[rapid deepening|rapidly intensify]].<ref name="great">{{cite book|author=Margaret Buchholz|author2=Larry Savadove|year=1993|title=Great Storms of the Jersey Shore|publisher=Down the Shore Publishing|isbn=0-945582-51-X|pages=150–151, 195}}</ref> On January 4, a buoy reported a minimum [[atmospheric pressure|barometric pressure]] of {{convert|993|mb|inHg|abbr=on}}, and [[maximum sustained wind]]s of about {{convert|45|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref name="chl"/> The system developed [[tropical cyclone|tropical characteristics]], including the development of an [[eye (cyclone)|eye]] feature in the center of the storm. Between 0500 and 0700 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]] on January 4, the storm moved ashore along the [[Eastern Shore of Virginia]],<ref name="dgs"/> about 25 mi (40 km) south of [[Ocean City, Maryland]].<ref name="dtic"/> It quickly weakened while moving across the [[Delmarva Peninsula]] and it emerged into the [[Chesapeake Bay]] by 1000 UTC that day. Three hours later, the storm was stalled over northern Virginia. A secondary low pressure area developed within the overall system further out to sea later on January 4.<ref name="dgs"/>
==Impact== [[File:1992 boardwalk damage.png|right|thumb|Boardwalk damage in [[Ocean City, New Jersey]]]] The nor'easter struck about two months after the destructive [[1991 Perfect Storm|Perfect Storm]], and preceded another damaging storm in [[December 1992 nor'easter|December 1992]].<ref name="dgs2">{{cite report|author=Kelvin W. Ramsey|author2=John H. Talley|author3=Darlene V. Wells|date=February 1993|publisher=Delaware Geological Survey|title=Summary Report: The Coastal Storm of December 10–14, 1992 Delaware and Maryland|accessdate=2012-03-18|url=http://www.dgs.udel.edu/sites/dgs.udel.edu/files/publications/OFR37.pdf|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923214312/http://www.dgs.udel.edu/sites/dgs.udel.edu/files/publications/OFR37.pdf|archivedate=2015-09-23|df=}}</ref> The storm produced strong winds and high surf during a new moon, which resulted in [[tide|astronomically high tides]].<ref name="dgs"/> Such tides caused coastal flooding and damage to dune systems.<ref name="book">{{cite book|author=Rick Schwartz|publisher=Blue Diamond Books|location=Alexandria, Virginia|year=2007|ISBN=978-0-9786280-0-0|title=Hurricanes and the Middle Atlantic States|pages=344–346|accessdate=2012-03-18|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t5U1CYKwQxcC&pg=PA343&lpg=PA343&dq=december+1992+nor'easter+mid+atlantic&source=bl&ots=shUUaT-FdP&sig=SxQ4mHGTTTJ6zzM2vRZ1SquKbmU&hl=en&ei=ESnOTLTDOsH58Aa5x6zCAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CCIQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=december%201992%20nor'easter%20mid%20atlantic&f=false}}</ref> Due to its small size, the storm's impact was highly localized and did not spread far to the north of the Delaware Bay.<ref name="dtic">{{cite report|author=Andrew W. Garcia|publisher=U.S. Army Corps of Engineers|date=January 1996|title=Halloween Storm and Storm of 4–5 January 1992: Implications for the Occurrence of Similar Event|accessdate=2012-03-19|url=http://www.dtic.mil/cgi-bin/GetTRDoc?AD=ADA304860|format=PDF}}</ref>
High waves flooded [[North Carolina Highway 12]] in the [[Outer Banks]] up to {{convert|2|ft|m|abbr=on}} deep, closing a {{convert|10|mi|km|abbr=on}} portion between [[Rodanthe, North Carolina|Rodanthe]] and [[Oregon Inlet]]. Portions of [[Kitty Hawk, North Carolina|Kitty Hawk]] and [[Pea Island National Wildlife Refuge|Pea Island]] were also flooded.<ref name="ap15">{{cite news|agency=Associated Press|newspaper=The Pittsburgh Press|date=1992-01-05|title=Storm pounds coast from Maryland to Long Island|accessdate=2012-03-19|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xnUcAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dGQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3836,830878&dq=storm&hl=en}}</ref> Offshore, the storm washed 500 drums of [[arsenic]] overboard a freighter, which prompted a [[United States Coast Guard|Coast Guard]] search for the toxic supplies.<ref name="ap15b"/> In Virginia, the storm produced a peak wind gust of {{convert|89|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} at [[Chincoteague, Virginia|Chincoteague]]. Along the eastern shore, high surf destroyed one house and damaged 110 camping trailers. Flooding and high winds damaged the [[Wallops Flight Facility]]. High winds downed trees and power lines, leaving 4,000 people without power. Property damage was estimated at $2.2 million (1992 USD).<ref name="ncdc"/>
In Maryland, the storm struck just before high tide.<ref name="dgs"/> A station on [[Assateague Island]] reported wind gusts of over {{convert|55|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} during the storm's closest approach.<ref name="chl"/> On the island, the storm killed 11 [[Chincoteague Pony|Assateague Ponies]] and 20 deer.<ref name="ap15b">{{cite news|agency=Associated Press|newspaper=The Reading Eagle|date=1992-01-04|title=500 arsenic drums lost in ocean during storm|accessdate=2012-03-19|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=gfohAAAAIBAJ&sjid=S6MFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1068,2658382&dq=storm&hl=en}}</ref> The cost to repair damages at [[Assateague Island National Seashore]] was estimated at $2.5 million (1992 USD).<ref name="ncdc"/> High winds in eastern Maryland left 32,000 people without power.<ref name="ncdc"/> The [[storm surge]] at [[Ocean City, Maryland|Ocean City]] was estimated at 6.6 ft (2 m), which washed over the city's dune system in several locations.<ref>{{cite conference|author=Jie Zheng, Robert G. Dean|year=1996|conference=Proceedings of the International Conference on Coastal Engineering, No 25|title=Comparisons of Erosion Models For Storms at Ocean City, MD|chapter=241|accessdate=2012-03-18|url=http://journals.tdl.org/ICCE/article/viewFile/5455/5131|format=PDF}}</ref> However, high waves destroyed the pier that the tidal gauge was on in the city. The combined effects of the nor'easter and the Perfect Storm from the previous October caused significant beach erosion along the Maryland coastline. In Ocean City, some streets lost a significant volume of sand while others gained sand.<ref name="chl">{{cite journal|author=Donald K. Stauble |title=Beach Nourishment Project Response and Design Evaluation: Ocean City, Maryland |publisher=US Army Corps of Engineers |date=August 1993 |accessdate=2012-03-19 |url=http://chl.erdc.usace.army.mil/Media/8/2/8/CERC-TR-93-13-REPORT-1.pdf |display-authors=etal |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090110050712/http://chl.erdc.usace.army.mil/Media/8/2/8/CERC-TR-93-13-REPORT-1.pdf |archivedate=2009-01-10 |df= }}</ref> The cost of the lost beach was estimated between $10–30 million (1992 [[United States dollar|USD]]).<ref>{{cite news|author=Tom Bowman|newspaper=Baltimore Sun|date=1992-01-07|title=Army Corps likely to pay for O.C. repairs Storm damage estimated at $10 million to $30 million|accessdate=2012-03-19|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1992-01-07/news/1992007048_1_beach-replenishment-storm-elected-officials}}</ref> Low-lying sections and coastal hotels in Ocean City were flooded.<ref name="ap15"/><ref name="ncdc"/> West of the city, the storm damaged several summer homes,<ref name="ap15"/> washing four houses off their foundations.<ref name="ncdc"/> Damage in Ocean City was estimated around $700,000 (1992 USD), much of which to a public golf course.<ref name="ap15b"/>
[[File:January 1992 Ocean City flood.png|right|thumb|Flooding in Ocean City, New Jersey]] The stronger northeast quadrant moved directly over Delaware for one tidal cycle, producing strong east-northeasterly wind gusts that peaked at {{convert|83|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} at a station along the [[Indian River (Delaware)|Indian River]].<ref name="dgs"/><ref name="ncdc"/> The highest tides and flooding along the Delaware coastline were between [[Bowers, Delaware|Bowers]] and [[Prime Hook National Wildlife Refuge]], where high waves built momentum from the Atlantic Ocean through the Delaware Bay.<ref name="dgs"/> In Bowers, the tide reached {{convert|8.76|ft|m|abbr=on}} along the [[Murderkill River]]; the reading was only {{convert|2|in|mm|abbr=on}} less than the record set during the [[Ash Wednesday Storm of 1962]]. The high tides flooded marsh vegetation in the town. In [[Lewes, Delaware|Lewes]], the highest tide was {{convert|7.40|ft|m|abbr=on}}, which was the second highest on record; only the 1962 storm was higher, which produced a tide of {{convert|8.05|ft|m|abbr=on}}. The storm caused significant flooding in [[Dewey Beach, Delaware|Dewey Beach]],<ref name="dgs2"/> where a high tide of {{convert|9.02|ft|m|abbr=on}} marked the second-highest tide in Delaware history.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Town Dewey Beach, Delaware|title=Storms of the Past|accessdate=2012-03-18|url=http://www.townofdeweybeach.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=trees.pageDetails&p=264-18-359}}</ref> The saltwater contaminated the town's water supply.<ref name="deseret">{{cite news|agency=Reuters|newspaper=The Deseret News|date=1992-01-05|title=Coastal storm pummels 2 states|accessdate=2012-03-19|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=wywhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=xHoFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2542,1267048&dq=storm&hl=en}}</ref> The ocean washed over dunes in several locations along Delaware Bay, including in [[Fowler Beach, Delaware|Fowler Beach]] where flooding reached {{convert|20|ft|m|abbr=on}} inland. Near [[Mispillion Light]], the high tides damaged the marina and several nearby buildings.<ref name="dgs"/> The high tides flooded marshes and low-lying areas throughout the state, which briefly closed portions of state highways [[Delaware Route 54|54]], [[Delaware Route 26|26]], and [[Delaware Route 1|1]].<ref name="dgs"/> High tides destroyed 11 blocks of the boardwalk in [[Rehoboth Beach, Delaware|Rehoboth Beach]] and half of the promenade at [[Bethany Beach, Delaware|Bethany Beach]].<ref name="book"/><ref name="deseret"/> At nearby [[South Bethany, Delaware|South Bethany]], high waves destroyed three houses.<ref name="ap15"/> Along the coast, the storm destroyed 15 houses and damaged 500 others, amounting to over $5 million (1992 USD) in property damage.<ref name="ncdc"/> In addition to the strong winds and high tides, the nor'easter produced light rainfall that did not cause any flooding. The highest total in the state was {{convert|1.06|in|mm|abbr=on}} in [[Georgetown, Delaware|Georgetown]].<ref name="dgs"/> Due to the damage, [[Kent County, Delaware|Kent]] and [[Sussex County, Delaware|Sussex]] counties were declared federal disaster areas on February 6; this allocated federal funding for repairing storm damage.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Federal Emergency Management Agency |date=2004-10-18 |title=Delaware Severe Coastal Storm: Major Disaster Declared February 6, 1992 (DR-933) |accessdate=2012-03-18 |url=http://www.fema.gov/news/eventcounties.fema?id=2133 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120103143947/http://www.fema.gov/news/eventcounties.fema?id=2133 |archivedate=January 3, 2012 |df= }}</ref> Then-governor [[Michael Castle]] activated the state's [[United States National Guard|National Guard]] to assist clearing highways and prevent civilian access to damaged areas.<ref name="ap15"/> Due to storm damage, access to Dewey Beach and Rehoboth Beach were restricted to residents.<ref name="deseret"/>
Further northeast, the nor'easter produced wind gusts of {{convert|60|mph|km/h|abbr=on}},<ref name="book"/> along with high tides; [[Steel Pier]] in [[Atlantic City, New Jersey|Atlantic City]] reported a peak tide of about {{convert|8|ft|m|abbr=on}}.<ref name="great"/> The ocean flooded under the boardwalk onto adjacent streets,<ref name="ap15"/> and to the west of the city, flooding closed portions of the [[White Horse Pike]].<ref name="ny15"/> In [[Cape May Point, New Jersey|Cape May Point]], the storm breached dunes that withstood the Perfect Storm, which flooded half of the borough. High tides also caused flooding in nearby [[Cape May, New Jersey|Cape May]], leaving behind {{convert|3|ft|m|abbr=on}} of sand in some locations. There was significant dune damage in [[Strathmere, New Jersey|Strathmere]] and [[Harvey Cedars, New Jersey|Harvey Cedars]].<ref name="great"/> The storm damaged the boardwalk in [[Ocean City, New Jersey|Ocean City]], and other coastal towns had damage to bulkheads and sea walls.<ref name="ncdc"/> About 3,000 people were left without power in [[Somers Point, New Jersey|Somers Point]].<ref name="ny15"/> The storm affected 4,000 houses, of which 76 had severe damage. Overall damage in the state was estimated at $45 million (1992 USD), of which around 30% was public parks and buildings.<ref name="ncdc">{{cite journal|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|title=Storm Data January 1992|volume=34|number=1|accessdate=2012-03-26|url=http://www1.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/orders/IPS-52F7F213-7369-43DA-BD73-064E7FABD74B.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> However, damage was less than that from the Perfect Storm in the previous October.<ref name="book"/> About 80 people evacuated to emergency shelters in South Jersey, and 95 residents of a nursing home in Atlantic City evacuated inland.<ref name="ap15"/><ref name="deseret"/> Due to the storm damage, then-governor [[James Florio|Jim Florio]] declared a state of emergency in [[Cape May County, New Jersey|Cape May]], [[Atlantic County, New Jersey|Atlantic]], [[Ocean County, New Jersey|Ocean]], and [[Monmouth County, New Jersey|Monmouth]] counties. Due to the successive impacts of nor'easters in October and January, the state government provided money to restore beaches.<ref name="great"/>
Further north, [[LaGuardia Airport]] outside [[New York City]] reported a wind gust of {{convert|48|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref name="ny15">{{cite news|author=Dennis Hevesi|date=1992-01-05|title=Winds From an Atlantic Storm Topple Trees and Tear at Moorings|newspaper=New York Times|accessdate=2012-03-19|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/01/05/nyregion/winds-from-an-atlantic-storm-topple-trees-and-tear-at-moorings.html}}</ref> Strong winds on [[Long Island]] knocked a tree onto a car, seriously injuring the driver.<ref name="ap15"/> Freezing rain from the storm caused traffic accidents, killing one person in [[White Creek, New York|White Creek]].<ref name="ncdc"/> In [[Oyster Bay (inlet), New York|Oyster Bay]], the winds pushed an oil barge into a small boat, causing heavy damage to the smaller vessel.<ref name="ap15"/> Moisture spread as far north as Maine, where the storm dropped freezing rain; this caused several car accidents that resulted in 11 injuries.<ref name="ncdc"/>
==See also== *[[1991 Perfect Storm]] *[[December 1992 nor'easter]] *[[1993 Storm of the Century]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1992 natural disasters in the United States|January 1992 nor'easter]] [[Category:1992 meteorology|January 1992 nor'easter]] [[Category:Nor'easters|January 1992 nor'easter]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Lead too short|date=June 2016}} This article is about the '''[[Kyoto Protocol]] and government action''' in relation to that treaty.
==Annex I==
In total, Annex I Parties managed a cut of 3.3% in [[greenhouse gas]] (GHG) emissions between 1990 and 2004 (UNFCCC, 2007, p. 11).<ref>{{Cite web |date=19 November 2007 |title=Compilation and synthesis of fourth national communications. Executive summary. Note by the secretariat. Document code: FCCC/SBI/2007/INF.6 |url=http://unfccc.int/documentation/documents/advanced_search/items/3594.php?rec=j&priref=600004368#beg |publisher=United Nations Office at Geneva, Switzerland |accessdate=17 May 2010}}</ref> In 2007, projections indicated rising emissions of 4.2% between 1990 and 2010. This projection assumed that no further mitigation action would be taken. The reduction in the 1990s was driven significantly by economic restructuring in the economies-in-transition (EITs. See the main [[Kyoto Protocol#Change in greenhouse gas emission since 1990|Kyoto Protocol]] article for the list of EITs). Emission reductions in the EITs had little to do with climate change policy (Carbon Trust, 2009, p. 24).<ref name=carbont/> Some reductions in Annex I emissions have occurred due to policy measures, such as promoting energy efficiency (UNFCCC, 2007, p. 11).
===Australia===
On the change of [[First Rudd ministry|government]] following the [[Australian general election, 2007|election in November 2007]], Prime Minister [[Kevin Rudd]] signed the ratification immediately after assuming office on 3 December 2007, just before the meeting of the [[2007 United Nations Climate Change Conference|UN Framework Convention on Climate Change]];<ref>{{cite news |url = http://abc.net.au/news/newsitems/200610/s1772952.htm |title = Govt still not serious about climate change: Labor |publisher = ABC News |date = 26 October 2006 |accessdate = 30 October 2006 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20071011163324/http://abc.net.au/news/newsitems/200610/s1772952.htm# |archive-date = 11 October 2007 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="australia signing">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/7124236.stm |title=Rudd takes Australia inside Kyoto |publisher=BBC News |date=3 December 2007 |accessdate=5 December 2007}}</ref> it took effect in March 2008.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7124236.stm |title=Australia's Rudd sworn in as PM |publisher=BBC News |date=3 December 2007 |accessdate=3 December 2007}}</ref> Australia's target is to limit its emissions to 8% above their 1990 level over the 2008–2012 period, i.e., their average emissions over the 2008–2012 period should be kept below 108% of their 1990 level (IEA, 2005, p. 51).<ref name=ieaaus>{{cite web |year=2005 |title=Energy Policies of IEA Countries – Australia- 2005 Review |url=http://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/australia2005.pdf |publisher=International Energy Agency website |accessdate=29 April 2010}}</ref> According to the Australian government, Australia should meet its Kyoto target (IEA, 2005, p. 56; DCCEE, 2010).<ref>{{Cite web |date=12 February 2010 |title=Department of Climate Change and Energy Efficiency – What the Government is doing |url=http://www.climatechange.gov.au/en/government.aspx |publisher=Department of Climate Change and Energy Efficiency, Commonwealth of Australia |accessdate=29 April 2010}}</ref>
When he was in the [[Opposition (Australia)|opposition]], Rudd commissioned [[Ross Garnaut]] to [[Garnaut Report|report]] on the economic effects of reducing greenhouse gas emissions. The report was submitted to the [[Australian government]] on 30 September 2008.
The policy of the Rudd government contrasts with that of the [[Howard Government|former Australian government]], which refused to ratify the agreement on the ground that following the protocol would be costly.<ref name="bbc-aus">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/4797339.stm |title=Howard rejects emissions targets |publisher=BBC News |date=16 August 2006 |accessdate=30 October 2006}}</ref>
====Policy====
Australia's position, under Prime Minister [[John Howard]], was that it did not intend to ratify the treaty (IEA, 2005, p. 51).<ref name=ieaaus/> The justification for this was that: *the treaty did not cover 70% of global emissions; *developing countries are excluded from emission limitations; *and the-then largest GHG emitter, the US, had not ratified the treaty. The Howard government did intend to meet its Kyoto target, but without ratification (IEA, 2005, p. 51).
As part of the 2004 budget, A$1.8 billion was committed towards its climate change strategy. A$700 million was directed towards low-emission technologies (IEA, 2005, p. 56). The Howard government, along with the United States, agreed to sign the [[Asia Pacific Partnership on Clean Development and Climate]] at the [[Association of Southeast Asian Nations|ASEAN]] regional forum on 28 July 2005. Furthermore, the state of [[New South Wales]] (NSW) commenced the NSW greenhouse gas abatement scheme.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.greenhousegas.nsw.gov.au/ |title=Greenhouse Gas Abatement Scheme |publisher=NSW Greenhouse Gas Abatement Scheme |accessdate=31 October 2006}}</ref> This mandatory scheme of greenhouse gas emissions trading commenced on 1 January 2003 and is currently in trial by the state government in NSW alone. Notably, this scheme allows accredited certificate providers to trade emissions from households in the state. As of 2006, the scheme is still in place despite the outgoing [[John Howard|Prime Minister]]'s clear dismissal of emissions trading as a credible solution to climate change.
Following the example of NSW, the national emissions trading scheme (NETS) has been established as an initiative of state and territory governments of Australia, all of which have Labor Party governments, except Western Australia.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.emissionstrading.net.au/home |title = National Emissions Trading Taskforce |accessdate = 31 October 2006 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20060918045454/http://www.emissionstrading.net.au/home# |archive-date = 18 September 2006 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref> The purpose of NETS is to establish an intra-Australian carbon trading scheme to coordinate policy among regions. As the [[Constitution of Australia]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://scaleplus.law.gov.au/html/pasteact/1/641/top.htm |title=Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act |publisher=The Attorney-General's Department |accessdate=31 October 2006 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061004014032/http://scaleplus.law.gov.au/html/pasteact/1/641/top.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 4 October 2006}}</ref> does not refer specifically to environmental matters (apart from water), the allocation of responsibility is to be resolved at a political level. In the later years of the Howard administration (1996–2007), the states governed by the Labor took steps to establish a NETS (a) to take action in a field where there were few mandatory federal steps and (b) as a means of facilitating ratification of the Kyoto Protocol by the incoming Labor government.
In May 2009, Kevin Rudd delayed and changed the carbon pollution reduction scheme:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.climatechange.gov.au/whitepaper/measures/index.html |title=Carbon Pollution Reduction Scheme – New measures |publisher=Climatechange.gov.au |date=6 May 2009 |accessdate=21 May 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090517023136/http://www.climatechange.gov.au/whitepaper/measures/index.html |archivedate=17 May 2009 }}</ref> * the scheme would begin in 2011/2012, a year later than initially scheduled (it had been scheduled to begin on 1 July 2010); * there would be one-year fixed price of A$10 per permit in 2011/2012 (previously, price was to under the price cap of $40); * there would be an unlimited amount of permits available from the government in the first year (previously, estimated 300 million tons of [[carbon dioxide]] (CO<sub>2</sub>) was to be auctioned off); * a higher percentage of permits would be handed out, rather than auctioned off (previously, 60% or 90% of permits were to be handed out); * compensation would be canceled in 2010/2011 and reduced in 2011/2012; * households can reduce their carbon footprint by buying and retiring permits into an Australian carbon trust (previously, no such scheme was included); * subject to an international agreement, Australia would commit to a reduction of 25% from the 2000 level by 2020 (previously, there was to be a reduction of 15%); * 5% out of the 25% reduction could be achieved by the government purchase of international off-sets (previously, no such scheme was included).
'''Greenpeace'''
[[Greenpeace]] has called clause 3.7 of the Kyoto Protocol the ''"Australia clause"'' on the ground that it unfairly made Australia a major beneficiary. The clause allows annex 1 countries with a high rate of land clearing in 1990 to set the level in that year as a base. Greenpeace argues that since Australia had an extremely high level of land clearing in 1990, Australia's "baseline" was unusually high compared to other countries.<ref name="aust clause">"[http://www.greenpeace.org/australia/issues/climate-change/solutions/political/kyoto-protocol/Australia Australia and the Kyoto Protocol]", Greenpeace Asia Pacific, accessed 18 May 2007.</ref>
====Emissions====
In 2002, Australia represented about 1.5% of global greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions (IEA, 2005, p. 51).<ref name=ieaaus/> Over the 1990–2002 period, Australia's gross emissions rose by 22%, which was surpassed by only four other [[International Energy Agency]] (IEA) members (IEA, 2005, p. 54). This was in large part due to economic growth. Net emissions (including changes in land-use and forestry) increased by 1.3% over this period. In 2005, Australia's GHG emissions<sup>a</sup> made up 1.2% of the global total (MNP, 2007).<ref name=mnp>{{cite web |year=2007 |author=MNP |title=Greenhouse gas emissions of countries in 2005 and ranking of their per capita emissions. Table 2.a. Top-20 countries of greenhouse emissions in 2006 from fossil fuels and cement production |url=http://www.pbl.nl/images/Top20-CO2andGHG-countries-in2006-2005(GB)_tcm61-36276.xls |publisher=Netherlands Environment Agency website |accessdate=1 May 2010}}</ref>
Per-capita emissions are a country's total emissions divided by its population (Banuri ''et al''., 1996, p. 95).<ref>{{cite book |year=1996 |author=Banuri, T.|title=Equity and Social Considerations. In: Climate Change 1995: Economic and Social Dimensions of Climate Change. Contribution of Working Group III to the Second Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (J.P. Bruce et al. Eds.) |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |location=Cambridge, U.K., and New York, N.Y., U.S.A. |isbn=978-0-521-56854-8 |doi=10.2277/0521568544|display-authors=etal}}</ref> In 2005, per capita emissions in Australia were 26.3 tons per capita<sup>a</sup> (MNP, 2007).
===Canada===
{{See also|Canada and the Kyoto Protocol}}
On 17 December 2002, Canada ratified the treaty that came into force in February 2005, requiring it to reduce emissions to 6% below 1990 levels during the 2008–2012 commitment period (IEA, 2004, p. 52).<ref name=ieacan>{{cite web |year=2004 |title=Energy Policies of IEA Countries – Canada- 2004 Review |url=http://www.iea.org/publications/free_new_Desc.asp?PUBS_ID=1468 |publisher=IEA website |accessdate=29 April 2010}}</ref> Under Canada's Kyoto Protocol Implementation Act (KPIA), the National Round Table on the Environment and the Economy (NRTEE) is required to respond to the government's climate change plans (Canadian Government, 2010).<ref>{{Cite web |date=13 April 2010 |title=Canada's Action on Climate Change – Action on Climate Change – United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) |url=http://www.climatechange.gc.ca/default.asp?lang=En&n=D6B3FF2B-1 |publisher=Canada's Action on Climate Change website |accessdate=29 April 2010}}</ref> In the assessment of NRTEE (2008), "Canada is not pursuing a policy objective of meeting the Kyoto Protocol emissions reductions targets. [...] [The] projected emissions profile described in the 2008 [government plan] would leave Canada in non-compliance with the Kyoto Protocol."<ref>{{Cite web |date = 1 August 2008 |title = Response of the National Round Table on the Environment and the Economy to its Obligations Under the Kyoto Protocol Implementation Act: Analysis and Assessment: 5.3 Effectiveness of Measures and Regulations in Meeting Canada’s Kyoto Protocol Obligations |url = http://www.ec.gc.ca/default.asp?lang=En&n=10A2099D-1&xml=10A2099D-6734-4EE5-853B-041E4512F07B&offset=7&toc=show |publisher = Environment Canada website |accessdate = 29 April 2010 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110611120529/http://www.ec.gc.ca/default.asp?lang=En&n=10A2099D-1&xml=10A2099D-6734-4EE5-853B-041E4512F07B&offset=7&toc=show# |archive-date = 11 June 2011 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref>
On 13 December 2011, a day after the end of the [[2011 United Nations Climate Change Conference]], Canada's environment minister, [[Peter Kent]], announced that [[Climate change in Canada|Canada]] would withdraw from the Kyoto Protocol.<ref name="vaughan 2011 canada withdrawal"> {{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2011/dec/13/canada-withdrawal-kyoto-protocol?intcmp=239 | last=Vaughan | first= A. | title=What does Canada's withdrawal from Kyoto protocol mean? | work= The Guardian | date=13 December 2011 | accessdate=17 December 2012}}</ref>
====Emissions====
In 2001, Canadian emissions had grown by more than 20% above their 1990 level (IEA, 2004, p. 49).<ref name=ieacan/> High population and economic growth, added to the expansion of CO<sub>2</sub> emissions-intensive sectors, such as [[oil sand]] production, were responsible for this growth in emissions. By 2004, CO<sub>2</sub> emissions had risen to 27% above the level in 1990.<ref>{{cite book |title=2006 Report of the Commissioner of the Environment and Sustainable Development |publisher=Office of the Auditor General of Canada |date=28 September 2006 |url=http://www.oag-bvg.gc.ca/domino/reports.nsf/html/c2006menu_e.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061003053647/http://www.oag-bvg.gc.ca/domino/reports.nsf/html/c2006menu_e.html |archivedate=3 October 2006}}</ref> In 2006 they were down to 21.7% above 1990 levels.<ref>{{cite book |title=National Inventory Report, 1990–2006 – Greenhouse Gas Sources and Sinks in Canada, Report Summary |publisher=Environment Canada |date=16 May 2008 |url=http://www.ec.gc.ca/pdb/ghg/inventory_report/2006/som-sum_eng.pdf |format=PDF}}</ref>
In 2005, Canada's GHG emissions<sup>a</sup> made up 2% of the global total (MNP, 2007).<ref name=mnp/> Per capita emissions in Canada were 23.2 tons per capita.
'''Projections'''
In 2004, Canada's emission projections under a business-as-usual scenario (i.e., predicted emissions should policy not be changed) indicated a rise of 33% on the 1990 level by 2010 (IEA, 2004, p. 52).<ref name=ieacan/> This is a gap of approximately 240 Mt between its target and projected emissions.
====Politics====
When the treaty was ratified in 2002, numerous polls showed support for the Kyoto protocol at around 70%.<ref>{{cite press release |title = Support (74%) Remains High for Kyoto Protocol |publisher = IPSOS News Center |url = http://www.ipsos-na.com/news/pressrelease.cfm?id=1667 |accessdate = 15 November 2005 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20051126162355/http://www.ipsos-na.com/news/pressrelease.cfm?id=1667 |archivedate = 26 November 2005 |df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title = Public Attitudes Towards the Kyoto Protocol |url = http://www.ekos.com/admin/articles/10June02KyotoProt.pdf |accessdate = 15 November 2005 |last = Graves |first = Frank |author2 = Boucher, Christian |publisher = Ekos Research Associates |format = PDF |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20051030033636/http://www.ekos.com/admin/articles/10June02KyotoProt.pdf |archivedate = 30 October 2005 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> Despite strong public support, there was still some opposition, particularly by the [[Canadian Alliance]], a precursor to the governing [[Conservative Party of Canada|Conservative Party]], some business groups,<ref>{{cite news |title=Business leaders call for climate change action |publisher=CBC |date=17 November 2005 |url=http://www.cbc.ca/money/story/2005/11/17/kyotobiz-051117.html }}</ref> and energy concerns, using arguments similar to those being voiced in the U.S. In particular, there was a fear that since U.S. companies would not be affected by the Kyoto Protocol, Canadian companies would be at a disadvantage. In 2005, a "war of words" was ongoing, primarily between [[Alberta]], Canada's primary oil and gas producer, and the federal government.
Between 1998 and 2004, Canada committed $3.7 billion towards investment on climate change activities (IEA, 2004, p. 52).<ref name=ieacan/><ref>{{cite news |title=Canada-Kyoto timeline |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/background/kyoto/timeline.html |date=11 October 2006 |accessdate=1 November 2006 |publisher=CBC News}}</ref> The Climate Change Plan for Canada, released in November 2002, described priority areas for climate change policy.
In January 2006, a Conservative minority government under [[Stephen Harper]] was elected, who previously has expressed opposition to Kyoto, and in particular to the international emission trading. [[Rona Ambrose]], who replaced [[Stéphane Dion]] as the environment minister, has since endorsed and expressed interests in some types of emission trading.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.canada.com/topics/news/national/story.html?id=37ccc2a8-b164-458b-a11c-21cab1236a5a&k=44333 |title = Ambrose drops hints that Canada's position on Kyoto may be changing |work = Canadian Press |date = 19 November 2006 |accessdate = 1 November 2006 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20071011111537/http://canada.com/topics/news/national/story.html?id=37ccc2a8-b164-458b-a11c-21cab1236a5a&k=44333# |archive-date = 11 October 2007 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref> On 25 April 2006, Ambrose announced that Canada would have no chance of meeting its targets under Kyoto, but would look to participate in the [[Asia-Pacific Partnership on Clean Development and Climate]] sponsored by the U.S. "We've been looking at the Asia-Pacific Partnership for a number of months now because the key principles around [it] are very much in line with where our government wants to go," Ambrose told reporters.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2006/04/25/ambrose060425.html |title=CBC News: "Canada supports six-nation climate change pact: Ambrose" |accessdate=28 May 2007 | date=25 April 2006}}</ref> On 2 May 2006, it was reported that the funding to meet the Kyoto standards had been cut, while the Harper government develops a new plan to take its place.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/05/02/AR2006050201774.html |work=[[The Washington Post]] |title=Canada Alters Course on Kyoto |date=3 May 2006 |accessdate=1 November 2006 | first=Doug | last=Struck}}</ref> As the co-chair of the UN Climate Change Conference in Nairobi in November 2006, the Canadian government received criticism from environmental groups and other governments for its position.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.macleans.ca/topstories/national/article.jsp?article=2006_11_16_1163698971 |work=Maclean's |title=Rona Ambrose goes from Ottawa to Nairobi, but can't shake her critics |date=16 November 2006}}</ref> On 4 January 2007, Rona Ambrose moved from the Ministry of the Environment to become Minister of Intergovernmental Affairs. The environment portfolio went to [[John Baird (Canadian politician)|John Baird]], the former President of the Treasury Board.
The federal government has introduced legislation to set mandatory emissions targets for industry, but they will not take effect until 2012, with a benchmark date of 2006 as opposed to Kyoto's 1990. The government has since begun working with opposition parties to modify the legislation.
A [[private member's bill]]<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.parl.gc.ca/39/1/parlbus/chambus/house/bills/private/C-288/C-288_1/C-288_cover-e.html |title= Canadian Parliament Bill C-288 "An Act to ensure Canada meets its global climate change obligations under the Kyoto Protocol" |publisher=House of Commons of Canada |accessdate=1 November 2006}}</ref> was put forth by [[Pablo Rodríguez (Canadian politician)|Pablo Rodriguez]], [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal]], to force the government to "ensure that Canada meets its global climate change obligations under the Kyoto Protocol." With the support of the Liberals, the [[New Democratic Party of Canada|New Democratic Party]] and the [[Bloc Québécois]], and with the current minority situation, the bill passed the [[House of Commons of Canada|House of Commons]] on 14 February 2007 with a vote of 161 to 113.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2007/02/14/kyoto-vote.html |title=Opposition MPs pass Kyoto bill despite Tory resistance |publisher=Canadian Broadcast Corporation |accessdate=15 February 2007 | date=14 February 2007}}</ref> The [[Senate of Canada|Senate]] passed the bill, and it received [[Royal Assent]] on 22 June 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.parl.gc.ca/legisinfo/index.asp?Language=E&Chamber=N&StartList=A&EndList=Z&Session=14&Type=0&Scope=I&query=4741&List=stat |title=LEGISINFO – The Library of Parliament's research tool for finding information on legislation |publisher=Parl.gc.ca |accessdate=21 May 2009}}</ref> However, the government, as promised, has largely ignored the bill, which was to force the government 60 days to form a detailed plan, citing economic reasons.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newswire.ca/en/releases/archive/April2007/19/c7015.html |title=CNW: According to some analysis, implementing Bill C-288 would push Canada into a recession |publisher=Newswire.ca |accessdate=21 May 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.corrieretandem.com/viewstory.php?storyid=8504 |title=Online magazine: Tandem |publisher=Corrieretandem.com |date=10 August 2008 |accessdate=21 May 2009}}</ref>
In May 2007, the [[Friends of the Earth]] sued the federal government for failing to meet the Kyoto Protocol obligations to cut greenhouse gas emissions. The obligations were based on a clause in the Canadian Environmental Protection Act that requires Ottawa to "prevent air pollution that violates an international agreement binding on Canada".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.seedmagazine.com/news/2007/05/friends_of_the_earth_sue_canad.php |title=Friends of the Earth sue Canada for breaching Kyoto Protocol |work=Seed Magazine |accessdate=1 June 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070622092334/http://www.seedmagazine.com/news/2007/05/friends_of_the_earth_sue_canad.php <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 22 June 2007}}</ref> Canada's obligation to the treaty began in 2008.
Regardless of the federal policy, some provinces are pursuing policies to restrain emissions, including [[Quebec]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mddep.gouv.qc.ca/changements/plan_action/index.htm |title=Québec, leader en changements climatiques |publisher=Ministère du Développement durable de l'Environnement et des Parcs |accessdate=21 May 2009}}</ref> [[Ontario]], British Columbia and [[Manitoba]] as part of the [[Western Climate Initiative]]. Since 2003 [[Alberta]] operates a carbon offset program.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://telegraphjournal.canadaeast.com/rss/article/676337 |title=Alberta leading the way in carbon-offset programs |work=Telegraph Journal |location=Saint John, New Brunswick, Canada |accessdate=8 December 2009}}</ref>
'''Environmental groups'''
Environmental groups in Canada are working together to demand that Canadian politicians take the threat of climate change seriously and make the necessary changes to ensure the safety and health of future generations. Participating groups have created a petition called [[KYOTOplus]], on which signatories commit to the following acts: <br />• set a national target to cut greenhouse gas emissions at least 25 per cent from 1990 levels by 2020; <br />• implement an effective national plan to reach this target and help developing countries adapt and build low-carbon economies; and <br />• adopt a strengthened second phase of the Kyoto Protocol at the United Nations climate change conference at Copenhagen, Denmark in December 2009.
[[KYOTOplus]] is a national, non-partisan, petition-centered campaign for urgent federal government action on climate change. There are over fifty partner organizations, including: [[Climate Action Network Canada]], [[Sierra Club Canada]], [[Sierra Youth Coalition]], [[Oxfam Canada]], the [[Canadian Youth Climate Coalition]], [[Greenpeace Canada]], KAIROS: Canadian Ecumenical Justice Initiatives and the David Suzuki Foundation.
====Withdrawal of Canada====
On 13 December 2011, Canada's environment minister, [[Peter Kent]], announced that Canada would withdraw from the Kyoto Protocol.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2011/dec/13/canada-pulls-out-kyoto-protocol?intcmp=122 |title=Canada pulls out of Kyoto protocol |newspaper=The Guardian |date= 13 December 2011 |accessdate=6 September 2012}}</ref> The announcement was a day after the end of the [[2011 United Nations Climate Change Conference]] (the 17th Conference of the Parties, or "COP 17").<ref name="vaughan 2011 canada withdrawal"/> At COP 17, the representatives of the Canadian government gave their support to a new international climate change agreement that "includes commitments from all major emitters."<ref name="2011 COP 17 Country Statement (Canada)"> {{citation | year=2011 | title=COP 17 Country Statement (Canada) | author=Canadian government | url=http://unfccc.int/files/meetings/durban_nov_2011/statements/application/pdf/111207_cop17_hls_canada.pdf | format=PDF | publisher=United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) }} </ref>{{Rp|1}} Canadian representatives also stated that "the Kyoto Protocol is not where the solution lies – it is an agreement that covers fewer than 30 per cent of global emissions (...)."<ref name="2011 COP 17 Country Statement (Canada)"/>{{Rp|2}}
The Canadian government invoked Canada's legal right to formally withdraw from the Kyoto Protocol on 12 December 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/politics/article/1100802--canada-withdrawing-from-kyoto?bn=1#article |title=Canada withdrawing from Kyoto |work=The Toronto Star |date= 12 December 2011 |accessdate=12 December 2011}}</ref> Canada was committed to cutting its greenhouse emissions to 6% below 1990 levels by 2012, but in 2009 emissions were 17% higher than in 1990. Environment minister [[Peter Kent]] cited Canada's liability to "enormous financial penalties" under the treaty unless it withdrew.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2011/dec/13/canada-pulls-out-kyoto-protocol |title=Canada pulls out of Kyoto protocol |work=The Guardian |accessdate=13 December 2011 |date=13 December 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://business.financialpost.com/2011/12/13/canada-to-pull-out-of-kyoto-protocol/ |title=Canada to pull out of Kyoto protocol |agency=Reuters |work=Financial Post |author=David Ljunggren and Randall Palmer |date=13 December 2011 |accessdate=9 January 2012 }}</ref> He also suggested that the recently signed [[2011 United Nations Climate Change Conference|Durban agreement]] may provide an alternative way forward.<ref name="bbc canada withdrawal"> {{cite news |title=Canada under fire over Kyoto protocol exit |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-16165033 |publisher=BBC News |date=13 December 2011}}</ref>
=====Commentary=====
{{Expand section|additional views on Canada's decision|date=December 2011}}
[[Christiana Figueres]], Executive Secretary of the UNFCCC, said that she regretted Canada's decision to withdraw from the Kyoto treaty, and that "[whether] or not Canada is a Party to the Kyoto Protocol, it has a legal obligation under the [UNFCCC] to reduce its emissions, and a moral obligation to itself and future generations to lead in the global effort."<ref> {{citation | date=13 December 2011 | title=Canada's withdrawal from Kyoto Protocol regrettable – UN climate official | url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?Cr1=&NewsID=40714&Cr=climate+change | publisher=United Nations (UN) News Centre | accessdate=17 December 2011 }} </ref>
Canada's decision received a mostly negative response from representatives of other ratifying countries.<ref name="bbc canada withdrawal"/> A spokesman for France's foreign ministry called the move "bad news for the fight against climate change."<ref name="bbc canada withdrawal"/> Japan's own environment minister, Goshi Hosono, urged Canada to stay in the protocol.<ref name="bbc canada withdrawal"/> Some countries, including India, were worried that Canada's decision might jeopardise future conferences.<ref name="bbc canada withdrawal"/>
A spokesperson for the island nation of Tuvalu, significantly threatened by rising sea levels, accused Canada of an "act of sabotage" against his country.<ref name="bbc canada withdrawal"/> Australian government minister [[Greg Combet]], however, defended the decision, saying that it did not mean Canada would not continue to "play its part in global efforts to tackle climate change".<ref name="bbc canada withdrawal"/> China called Canada's decision to withdraw from the Kyoto Protocol "regrettable" and said that it went against the efforts of the international community. Canada's move came days after climate-change negotiators met to hammer-out a global deal in Durban, South Africa.<ref>{{cite web|title=China Calls Canada's Kyoto Protocol Withdrawal 'Regrettable'|url=http://www.voanews.com/tibetan-english/news/China--Calls-Canadas-Kyoto--Protocol-Withdrawal-Regrettable-135578288.html|publisher=Voice of America|accessdate=14 June 2012|author=Stephanie Ho|date=14 December 2011}}</ref>
Foreign Ministry spokesman Liu Weimin expressed China's dismay at the news that Canada had pulled out of the Kyoto Protocol. Noting that the timing was particularly bad, because negotiators at the just-concluded Durban conference made what he described as important progress on the issue of the Kyoto Protocol's second commitment period.<ref>{{cite web|title=May accuses Harper of breaking law over Kyoto|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/story/2011/12/13/pol-may-kyoto.html|publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation News|accessdate=14 June 2012|author=Meagan Fitzpatrick|date=13 December 2011}}</ref>
The UK's Guardian newspaper reported<ref name="vaughan 2011 canada withdrawal"/> on Canada's decision to withdraw from the Kyoto treaty. According to the Guardian, "Canada's inaction was blamed by some on its desire to protect the lucrative but highly polluting exploitation of tar sands, the second biggest oil reserve in the world."<ref name="vaughan 2011 canada withdrawal"/>{{lopsided|date=December 2011}}
===Europe===
====European Union====
{{Refimprove section|date=May 2010}} {{See also|Energy policy of the European Union}}
On 31 May 2002, all fifteen then-members of the [[European Union]] deposited the relevant ratification paperwork at the UN. Under the Kyoto Protocol, the 15 member countries that were Member States of the EU when the Protocol was agreed (EU-15) are committed to reducing their collective GHG emissions in the period 2008–12 to 8% below levels in 1990 (EEA, 2009, p. 9).<ref>{{cite web |year=2009 |title=EEA Report No 9/2009. Greenhouse gas emission trends and projections in Europe 2009: Tracking progress towards Kyoto targets |url=http://www.eea.europa.eu/publications/eea_report_2009_9 |publisher=European Environment Agency website |accessdate=1 May 2010}}</ref> All but one EU Member State (Austria) anticipate that they will meet their commitments under the Kyoto Protocol (EEA, 2009, pp. 11–12).
Denmark has committed itself to reducing its emissions by 21%. On 10 January 2007, the [[European Commission]] announced plans for a [[Energy policy of the European Union|European Union energy policy]] that included a unilateral 20% reduction in GHG emissions by 2020.
The EU has consistently been one of the major nominal supporters of the Kyoto Protocol, negotiating hard to get wavering countries on board.{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}}
In December 2002, the EU created an [[European Union Emission Trading Scheme|emissions trading system]] (EU ETS) in an effort to meet these tough targets. Quotas were introduced in six key industries: energy, steel, cement, glass, brick making, and paper/cardboard. There are also fines for member nations that fail to meet their obligations, starting at €40/ton of carbon dioxide in 2005, and rising to €100/ton in 2008.
The position of the EU is not without controversy in Protocol negotiations, however.{{According to whom|date=May 2010}} One criticism is that, rather than reducing 8%, all the EU member countries should cut 15% as the EU insisted a uniform target of 15% for other developed countries during the negotiation while allowing itself to share a big reduction in the former East Germany to meet the 15% goal for the entire EU.{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}} According to Aldy ''et al''. (2003, p. 7), the "hot air" in German and UK targets allows the EU to meet its Kyoto target at low cost.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Thirteen Plus One: A Comparison of Global Climate Policy Architectures |date=9 September 2003 |author=Robert N. Stavins |author2=Joseph E. Aldy |author3=Scott Barrett |journal=Climate Policy |volume=3 |issue=3 |pages=373–397 |url=http://belfercenter.ksg.harvard.edu/publication/17261/thirteen_plus_one.html |accessdate=2 April 2010 |doi=10.1016/j.clipol.2003.09.004|hdl=10419/118092 }}</ref>
Both the EU (as the [[European Community]]) and its member states are signatories to the Kyoto treaty. Greece, however was excluded from the Kyoto Protocol on Earth Day (22 April 2008) due to unfulfilled commitment of creating the adequate mechanisms of monitoring and reporting emissions, which is the minimum obligation, and delivering false reports by having no other data to report. A United Nations committee has decided to reinstate Greece in the emissions-trading system of the Kyoto Protocol after a seven-month suspension (on 15 November).
'''Emissions'''
In 2005, the EU-27 made up 11% of total global GHG emissions<sup>a</sup> (MNP, 2007).<ref name=mnp/> Per capita emissions<sup>a</sup> were 10.6 tons per capita.
Transport CO<sub>2</sub> emissions in the EU grew by 32% between 1990 and 2004.{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}} The share of transport in CO<sub>2</sub> emissions was 21% in 1990, but by 2004 this had grown to 28%.{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}} Current EU projections suggest that by 2008 the EU will be at 4.7% below 1990 levels.{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}}
=====France===== France's Kyoto commitment is to cap its emissions at their 1990 levels (Stern, 2007, p. 456).<ref name=stern>{{cite web |year=2007 |title=Stern Review on the Economics of Climate Change (pre-publication edition) |author=Stern, N. |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=Cambridge, U.K., and New York, N.Y., U.S.A. |url=http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/sternreview_index.htm |accessdate=25 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5nCeyEYJr?url=http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/sternreview_index.htm |archivedate=31 January 2010 |df= }}</ref> The country has a national objective to reduce emissions by 25% from their 1990 levels by 2020, and a long-term target to reduce emissions 75–80% by 2050.
In 2002, France's total GHG emissions were roughly equivalent to 1990 levels, and 6.4% below 1990 levels when accounting for [[carbon sink|sink]] enhancements, as allowed under the Protocol (IEA, 2004, p. 58).<ref>{{cite web |year=2004 |title=Energy Policies of IEA Countries – France- 2004 Review |url=http://www.iea.org/publications/free_new_Desc.asp?PUBS_ID=1301 |publisher=IEA website |accessdate=2 May 2010}}</ref> In 2001, France's per capita emissions were 6.32 tCO<sub>2</sub> per capita. Only five other IEA countries had lower levels (p. 59). France's CO<sub>2</sub> intensity of GDP (energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions per gross domestic production (GDP)) was the fifth-lowest among all IEA countries.
In 2004, France shut down its last coal mine, and now gets 80% of its electricity from [[nuclear power]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/3651881.stm |title=Europe | France closes its last coal mine |publisher=BBC News |date=23 April 2004 |accessdate=21 May 2009}}</ref> and therefore has relatively low CO<sub>2</sub> emissions, except for its transport sector.<ref>{{cite press release |url=http://www.ieer.org/reports/energy/france/ |title=France Can Phase Out Nuclear Power and Achieve Low Carbon Dioxide Emissions |publisher=Institute for Energy and Environmental Research |date=4 May 2006 |accessdate=21 May 2009}}</ref>
=====Germany===== {{Main|German response to Kyoto Protocol}}
Germany has taken on a target under the Kyoto Protocol to reduce its GHG emissions by 21% compared with the base year 1990 (and in some cases, 1995) (IEA, 2007, pp. 44–45).<ref>{{cite web |year=2007 |title=Energy Policies of IEA Countries – Germany- 2007 Review |url=http://www.iea.org/publications/free_new_Desc.asp?PUBS_ID=1922 |pages=184 |publisher=International Energy Agency (IEA), |location=Paris |accessdate=2 May 2010}}</ref> Through 2004, Germany reduced its total GHG emissions by 17.4% (p. 45). Including the effects of land-use change increases this to 18.5%. The two main approaches Germany has used to meet its Kyoto target are reductions from the EU ETS, and reductions from the transport, household, and [[small business]] sectors (p. 51).
Germany's progress towards its Kyoto target benefits from its reunification in 1990 (Liverman, 2008, p. 12).<ref name=liverman>{{cite journal |year = 2008 |title = Conventions of climate change: constructions of danger and the dispossession of the atmosphere |doi = 10.1016/j.jhg.2008.08.008 |author = Liverman, D. M. |journal = Journal of Historical Geography |url = http://www.eci.ox.ac.uk/~dliverma/CV/JHGE07-17.pdf |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20091204180524/http://www.eci.ox.ac.uk/~dliverma/CV/JHGE07-17.pdf |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 4 December 2009 |accessdate = 8 August 2009 |volume = 35 |pages = 279 }}</ref> This is because of the reduction in emissions of East Germany after the fall of the Berlin Wall. CO<sub>2</sub> emissions in Germany fell 12% between 1990 and 1995 (Barrett, 1998, p. 34).<ref name=barrett>{{cite journal |year = 1998 |volume = 14 |issue = 4 |title = Political Economy of the Kyoto Protocol |author = Barrett, S. |journal = Oxford Review of Economic Policy |url = http://center.uvt.nl/staff/smulders/env/barret98.pdf |pages = 20–39 |accessdate = 18 April 2010 |doi = 10.1093/oxrep/14.4.20 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20040110100303/http://center.uvt.nl/staff/smulders/env/barret98.pdf# |archive-date = 10 January 2004 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref> Germany reduced gas emissions by 22.4% between 1990 and 2008.<ref>{{cite web |title=GHG DATA 2006 – Highlights from Greenhouse Gas (GHG) Emissions Data for 1990–2004 for annex I parties |url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/,tt7m1/wissen/763/449492/text/ |newspaper=[[Sueddeutsche Zeitung]] |date=27 November 2008 |accessdate=27 November 2008}}</ref>
On 28 June 2006, the German government announced that it would exempt its coal industry from requirements under the E.U. internal emission trading system. [[Claudia Kemfert]], an energy professor at the German Institute for Economic Research in Berlin said, "For all its support for a clean environment and the Kyoto Protocol, the cabinet decision is very disappointing. The energy lobbies have played a big role in this decision."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/06/29/business/worldbusiness/29green.html?ex=1309233600&en=4cd4442637d83026&ei=5088&partner=rssnyt&emc=rss |work=[[The New York Times]] |title=New German Rule Could Increase Greenhouse Gas Emissions |date=29 June 2006 |accessdate=1 November 2006 | first=Judy | last=Dempsey}}</ref> However, Germany's voluntary commitment to reduce CO<sub>2</sub> emissions by 21% from the level in 1990 has practically been met, because emission has already been reduced by 19%. Germany is thus contributing 75% of the 8% reduction promised by the E.U.<ref>{{cite press release |publisher=The Press and Information Office of the Federal Government (Presse und Informationsamt der Bundesregierung) |url=http://www.bundesregierung.de/nn_264718/Content/EN/StatischeSeiten/Schwerpunkte/Energie-der-Zukunft/deutschlands-beitrag-zur-internationalen-energie-und-klimapolitik.html |title=Germany's contribution to international energy and climate policy |date=16 February 2005 |accessdate=21 May 2009}}</ref>
=====United Kingdom===== According to the UK government, projections indicate that the UK's GHG emissions will fall about 23% below base year levels by 2010 (DECC, 2009, p. 3).<ref>{{cite web |year=2009 |title=The UK's Fifth National Communication under the United Framework Convention on Climate Change |url=http://www.decc.gov.uk/Media/viewfile.ashx?FilePath=What%20we%20do\Global%20climate%20change%20and%20energy\Global%20climate%20change%20the%20issue\International%20Strategy\1_20090605170212_e_@@_fifthcommunicationunfccc.pdf&filetype=4 |publisher=Department of Energy and Climate Change |location=London |accessdate=2 May 2010}}</ref> The UK's Kyoto target of a 12.5% reduction in emissions on their 1990 level (Stern, 2007, p. 456)<ref name=stern/> benefits from the country's relatively high emissions in that year (1990) (Liverman, 2008, p. 12).<ref name=liverman/> Compared to their 1990 level, UK {{CO2}} emissions in 1995 were lower by 7%. This was despite the fact that the UK had not adopted a radical policy to reduce emissions (Barrett, 1998, p. 34).<ref name=barrett/>
Since 1990, the UK has privatized its energy-consuming industries, which has helped to increase their energy efficiency (US Senate, 2005, p. 218).<ref>{{Cite web |date=5 October 2005 |title=Prepared statement of Michael Grubb. In: S. Hrg. 109-1016 – Kyoto Protocol: Assessing the Status of Efforts to Reduce Greenhouse Gases, Committee on Environment and Public Works |author=US Senate |publisher=US Government Print Office |url=http://www.access.gpo.gov/congress/senate/senate09sh109.html |accessdate=16 April 2010}}</ref> The UK has also liberalized its electricity and gas systems, resulting in a change from coal to gas (the "dash for gas"), which has lowered emissions. It is estimated that these changes have contributed about half of the total observed reductions in UK CO<sub>2</sub> emissions.
The [[energy policy of the United Kingdom]] fully endorses goals for [[carbon dioxide emissions]] reduction and has committed to proportionate reduction in national emissions on a phased basis.{{According to whom|date=April 2010}} The U.K. is a signatory to the Kyoto Protocol.
On 13 March 2007, a draft [[United Kingdom Climate Change Bill|Climate Change Bill]] was published after cross-party pressure over several years, led by environmental groups. Informed by the Energy White Paper 2003,<ref>[http://www.dti.gov.uk/energy/policy-strategy/energy-white-paper-2003/page21223.html Energy White Paper 2003] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081221143624/http://www.dti.gov.uk/energy/policy-strategy/energy-white-paper-2003/page21223.html# |date=21 December 2008 }}, [[Department of Trade and Industry (United Kingdom)|Department of Trade and Industry]], published February 2002, accessed 19 May 2007</ref> the bill aims to achieve a mandatory reduction of 60% in the [[carbon emission]] from the 1990 level by 2050, with an intermediate target of between 26% and 32% by 2020.<ref>[http://www.defra.gov.uk/news/2007/070313a.htm New Bill and strategy lay foundations for tackling climate change] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927000610/http://www.defra.gov.uk/news/2007/070313a.htm |date=27 September 2007 }}, [[Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs]], published 13 March 2007. Retrieved 13 March 2007.</ref> On 26 November 2008, the Climate Change Act became law with a target of 80% reduction over 1990.<ref>[http://www.decc.gov.uk/en/content/cms/legislation/en/content/cms/legislation/cc_act_08/cc_act_08.aspx Climate Change Act 2008] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100919043458/http://decc.gov.uk/en/content/cms/legislation/en/content/cms/legislation/cc_act_08/cc_act_08.aspx# |date=19 September 2010 }}, [[Department of Energy and Climate Change]] webpage, retrieved 11 October 2009.</ref> The U.K. is the first country to ratify a law with such a long-range and significant carbon reduction target.
The U.K. currently [[Energy use and conservation in the United Kingdom#Carbon emissions|appears on course]] to meet its Kyoto limitation for the basket of greenhouse gases, assuming the government is able to curb CO₂ emissions between 2007 and 2008 to 2012.<ref name="defra1">{{cite web |url= http://www.defra.gov.uk/news/2007/070131a.htm |publisher=[[DEFRA]] |title= 2005 UK climate change sustainable development indicator and greenhouse gas emissions final figures |accessdate=22 June 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070505095844/http://www.defra.gov.uk/news/2007/070131a.htm|archivedate = 5 May 2007}}</ref> Although the overall greenhouse gas emissions in the UK have fallen, annual net [[carbon dioxide]] emission has increased by about 2% since the Labour Party came to power in 1997.<ref name="defra1"/> As a result, it now seems highly unlikely that the government will be able to honour its pledge to cut carbon dioxide emissions by 20% from the 1990 level by 2010,<ref name="defra1"/> unless an immediate and drastic action is taken under after the ratification of the [[United Kingdom Climate Change Bill|Climate Change Bill]].
====Norway====
Norway's commitment under the Kyoto Protocol is to restrict its increase of GHGs to 1% above the 1990 level by the commitment period 2008–2012 (IEA, 2005, p. 46).<ref>{{cite web |year=2005 |title=Energy Policies of IEA Countries – Norway- 2005 Review |url=http://www.iea.org/publications/free_new_Desc.asp?PUBS_ID=1580 |publisher=International Energy Agency (IEA) |location=Paris |accessdate=3 May 2010}}</ref> In 2003, total emissions were 9% above the 1990 level. 99% of Norway's electricity from CO<sub>2</sub>-free [[hydropower]]. Oil and [[natural gas|gas]] extraction activities contributed 74% to the total increase of CO<sub>2</sub> in the period 1990–2003.
The Norwegian government (2009, p. 11) projected a rise in GHG emissions of 15% from 1990 to 2010.<ref>{{Cite web |date=December 2009 |author=Norwegian government |title=Norway's Fifth National Communication under the Framework Convention on Climate Change. Status report as of December 2009. Norwegian Ministry of the Environment |url=http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/natc/nor_nc5.pdf |publisher=UNFCCC website |accessdate=3 May 2010}}</ref> Measures and policies adopted after autumn 2008 are not included in the baseline scenario (i.e., the predicted emissions that would occur without additional policy measures) for this projection (p. 55).
Between 1990 and 2007, Norway's greenhouse gas emissions increased by 12%.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ssb.no/english/subjects/01/04/10/klimagassn_en/ |title=Statistics Norway, ''Strong increase in greenhouse gas emissions'' |publisher=Ssb.no |accessdate=21 May 2009}}</ref> As well as directly reducing their own greenhouse gas emissions, Norway's idea for carbon neutrality is to finance reforestation in China, a legal provision of the Kyoto protocol.
===Japan=== Japan ratified the Kyoto Protocol in June 2002, and has committed to reducing its GHG emissions by 6% below their 1990 levels (IEA, 2008, p. 47).<ref>{{cite book |year=2008 |title=Energy Policies of IEA Countries – Japan- 2008 Review |url=http://www.iea.org/publications/free_new_Desc.asp?PUBS_ID=2031 |publisher=International Energy Agency (IEA) |location=Paris |accessdate=7 June 2010}}</ref> Estimates for 2005 showed that Japan's emissions were 7.8% higher than in the base year.
To meet its Kyoto target, the government aims for a 0.6% reduction in domestic GHG emissions compared with the base year. It also aims to meet part of its target through a forest sink of 13 million tonnes of carbon, which is equivalent to a 3.8% cut. Another reduction of 1.6% is aimed for using the Kyoto [[flexible mechanisms]].
According to IEA (2008, p. 45), Japan is a world leader in the field of [[sustainable energy]] policies. The legislation guiding Japan's efforts to reduce emissions is the Kyoto Protocol Target Achievement Plan, passed in 2005 and later amended (p. 47). This Plan includes about 60 policies and measures. Most of these policies and measures are related to improved energy efficiency.
When measured using market exchange rates, Japan's energy intensity in terms of total primary energy supply per unit of GDP is the lowest among IEA countries (p. 53). Measured in terms of [[purchasing power parity]], its energy intensity is one of the lowest.
'''Emissions'''
In 2005, Japan's energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> per capita emissions were 9.5 metric tons per head of population (World Bank, 2010, p. 362).<ref name=wdr/> Japan's total energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions made up 4.57% of global emissions in this year. Over the period 1850–2005, Japan's cumulative energy-related CO<sub>2</sub> emissions were 46.1 billion metric tons.
===New Zealand=== {{Expand section|1=More information on New Zealand's climate change policies|date=November 2012}} New Zealand signed the [[Kyoto Protocol]] to the UNFCCC on 22 May 1998 and ratified it on 19 December 2002. New Zealand's target is to limit '''net''' greenhouse gas emissions for the five-year 2008–2012 commitment period to five times the 1990 '''gross''' volume of GHG emissions. New Zealand may meet this target by '''either''' reducing emissions '''or''' by obtaining carbon credits from the international market or from domestic carbon sinks.<ref name="mfatkp">{{cite web |url=http://www.mfat.govt.nz/Treaties-and-International-Law/03-Treaty-making-process/National-Interest-Analyses/0-Kyoto-Protocol-Part-I.php#obligations |title=The Kyoto Protocol |publisher=New Zealand Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade |date=16 July 2007 |accessdate=1 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65PMqdPxr?url=http://www.mfat.govt.nz/Treaties-and-International-Law/03-Treaty-making-process/2-National-Interest-Analyses/0-Kyoto-Protocol-Part-I.php |archivedate=12 February 2012}}</ref> The credits may be any of the Kyoto units; [[Assigned amount units]] (AAU), removal units (RMU), [[Emission Reduction Unit]]s (ERU) and [[Certified Emission Reduction]] (CER) units.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://unfccc.int/kyoto_protocol/mechanisms/emissions_trading/items/2731.php |title=Emissions Trading |publisher=UNFCCC |accessdate=17 February 2010 }}</ref> In April 2012, the projection of New Zealand's net Kyoto position was a surplus of 23.1 million emissions units valued at NZ$189 million, based on an international carbon price of 5.03 Euro per tonne.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.mfe.govt.nz/issues/climate/greenhouse-gas-emissions/net-position/ |title = New Zealand's net position under the Kyoto Protocol |last=MfE |date=April 2012 |accessdate=13 April 2012 |publisher = Ministry for the Environment }}</ref> On 9 November 2012, the New Zealand Government announced it would make climate pledges for the period from 2013 to 2020 under the UNFCCC process instead of adopting a binding limit under a second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol.<ref>{{cite press release |url= http://beehive.govt.nz/release/new-zealand-commits-un-framework-convention |title= New Zealand Commits to UN Framework Convention |publisher= New Zealand Government |date=9 November 2012 |accessdate=12 November 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10846322 |title=NZ says no to second stage of Kyoto Protocol |agency=AP |work=The Herald |date=9 November 2012 |accessdate=12 November 2012}}</ref>
At the [[2012 United Nations Climate Change Conference]] New Zealand was awarded two 'Fossil of the Day' awards for "actively hampering international progress".<ref name="3news.co.nz">{{cite news | url= http://www.3news.co.nz/NZ-hampering-climate-change-talks/tabid/1160/articleID/278239/Default.aspx | publisher=3 News NZ | title= NZ 'hampering' climate change talks | date=27 November 2012}}</ref> The New Zealand Youth Delegation heavily criticised the New Zealand government, saying New Zealand's decision not to sign up for a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol<ref>{{cite news | url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Key-defends-no-to-Kyoto-Protocol/tabid/1607/articleID/276309/Default.aspx | publisher=3 News NZ | title= Key defends 'no' to Kyoto Protocol | date=12 November 2012}}</ref> was "embarrassing, short-sighted and irresponsible".<ref name="3news.co.nz"/>
===Russia===
{{See also|Energy policy of Russia}}
Under the Kyoto Protocol, the Russian Federation committed itself to keeping its GHG emissions at the base year level during the first Kyoto commitment period from 2008–2012 (UNFCCC, 2009, p. 3).<ref>{{Cite web |date=31 August 2009 |title=Report of the centralized in-depth review of the fourth national communication of the Russian Federation. Document code: FCCC/IDR.4/RUS |url=http://unfccc.int/documentation/documents/advanced_search/items/3594.php?rec=j&priref=600005423#beg |publisher=United Nations Office at Geneva, Switzerland |accessdate=3 May 2010}}</ref> UNFCCC (2009, p. 11) reported that Russian GHG emissions were projected to decline by 28% relative to base year level by 2010.
The process of economic transition in the Russian Federation was accompanied by a sharp decline in its GDP in the 1990s (p. 4). Since 1998, the Russian Federation has experienced strong economic growth. In the period 1990–2006, emissions decreased by 33%. The difference between GDP and emissions was mainly driven by: *shifts in the structure of the economy; *reduced share of oil and coal in the primary energy supply and an increase in the share of natural gas and [[nuclear power]]; *a decline in the transport and agriculture sectors; *a decrease in population; *an increase in [[Efficient energy use|energy efficiency]].
Russia accounts for about two-thirds of the expected emission savings from [[Joint Implementation]] (JI) projects by 2012 (Carbon Trust, 2009, p. 21).<ref name=carbont/> These savings are projected to amount to 190 megatonnes of [[carbon dioxide equivalent]] (CO<sub>2</sub>-eq) over the 2008–2012 period (p. 23).
'''Politics'''
[[Vladimir Putin]] approved the treaty on 4 November 2004, and Russia officially notified the United Nations of its ratification on 18 November 2004. The issue of Russian ratification was particularly closely watched in the international community, as the accord was brought into force 90 days after Russian ratification (16 February 2005).
President Putin had earlier decided in favor of the protocol in September 2004, along with the Russian cabinet,<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.mosnews.com/money/2004/09/30/kyotoapproved.shtml |archive-url = http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20090708032258/http://www.mosnews.com/money/2004/09/30/kyotoapproved.shtml |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 8 July 2009 |title = Russian Government Approves Kyoto Protocol Ratification |publisher = mosnews.com |date = 30 September 2004 |accessdate = 2 November 2006 }}</ref> against the opinion of the Russian Academy of Sciences, of the Ministry for Industry and Energy, and of the then-president's economic adviser, [[Andrey Illarionov]], and in exchange for the EU's support for Russia's admission into the [[WTO]].<ref>{{cite news |url = http://english.pravda.ru/main/18/88/354/14495_kyoto.html |newspaper = Pravda |title = Russia forced to ratify Kyoto Protocol to become WTO member |date = 26 October 2004 |accessdate = 3 November 2006 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070108001200/http://english.pravda.ru/main/18/88/354/14495_kyoto.html# |archive-date = 8 January 2007 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/05/22/business/international-business-europe-backs-russian-entry-into-wto.html |newspaper=The New York Times |title= Europe Backs Russian Entry into W.T.O. |first=Erin E. |last=Arvedlund |date=22 May 2004 |accessdate=17 May 2009}}</ref> As anticipated, after this, ratification by the lower (22 October 2004) and upper house of parliament did not encounter any obstacles.
There is an ongoing scientific debate on whether Russia will actually gain from selling credits for unused AAUs.
===United States=== {{See also|Energy policy of the United States}} <!--################################################################################################################################ PLEASE READ: Before you remove the line saying that the United States is the largest emitter of Carbon Dioxide and has been overtaken by China, please note that we are waiting for an OFFICIAL report stating this, and once it is released the article will be updated as needed. Thank you. #################################################################################################################################-->
The United States has not ratified the Kyoto Protocol (IEA, 2007, p. 90).<ref name=ieaus>{{cite web |year=2007 |title=Energy Policies of IEA Countries – the United States of America- 2007 Review |url=http://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/us2007.pdf |publisher=International Energy Agency (IEA) |location=Paris |accessdate=3 May 2010}}</ref> Doing so would have committed it to reduce GHG emissions by 7% below 1990 levels by 2012. Emissions of GHGs in the US increased by 16% between 1990 and 2005 (IEA, 2007, p. 83).<ref name=ieaus/> In this period, the most substantial increase in volume were emissions from energy use, followed by industrial processes.
In 2002, the US government set a goal to reduce the GHG emissions of the US economy per unit of economic output (the emissions intensity of the economy) (IEA, 2007, p. 87).<ref name=ieaus/> The set goal is to reduce the GHG intensity of the US economy by 18% by 2012. To achieve this, policy has focused on supporting [[energy development|energy research and development]], including support for [[carbon capture and storage]] (CCS), [[renewables]], [[methane]] capture and use, and nuclear power. The [[America's Climate Security Act of 2007]], also more commonly referred to in the U.S. as the "[[Cap and trade]] Bill", was proposed for greater U.S. alignment with the Kyoto standards and goals.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://lieberman.senate.gov/documents/amendment.pdf# |title=Archived copy |access-date=26 March 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090813072003/http://lieberman.senate.gov/documents/amendment.pdf# |archive-date=13 August 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
====Emissions==== Between 2001–2007, growth in US CO<sub>2</sub> emissions was only 3%, comparable with to that of IEA Europe, and lower than that of a number of other countries, some of which are parties to the Kyoto Protocol (IEA, 2007, p. 90).<ref name=ieaus/> In 2005, the US made up 16% of global GHG emissions,<sup>a</sup> and had per capita emissions of 24.1 tons of GHG per capita (MNP, 2007).<ref name=mnp/>
====Politics==== The United States (US), although a signatory to the Kyoto Protocol, has neither ratified nor withdrawn from the Protocol. The signature alone is merely symbolic, as the Kyoto Protocol is non-binding on the United States unless ratified.
=====Clinton administration===== On 25 July 1997, before the Kyoto Protocol was finalized (although it had been fully negotiated, and a penultimate draft was finished), the US Senate unanimously passed by a 95–0 vote the [[Byrd–Hagel Resolution]] (S. Res. 98),<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.nationalcenter.org/KyotoSenate.html |title = Text of the Byrd–Hagel Resolution |date = 25 July 1997 |accessdate = 5 November 2006 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100626110143/http://www.nationalcenter.org/KyotoSenate.html |archivedate = 26 June 2010 |df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=105&session=1&vote=00205 |title= U.S. Senate Roll Call Votes 105th Congress – 1st Session:S.Res. 98 |date=25 July 1997 |accessdate=31 January 2007}}</ref> which stated the sense of the Senate was that the United States should not be a signatory to any protocol that did not include binding targets and timetables for developing nations as well as industrialized nations or "would result in serious harm to the economy of the United States". On 12 November 1998, Vice President [[Al Gore]] symbolically signed the protocol.
